tasks: Select field with well-drained loamy soil (pH 6.0–7.5), full sunlight, no waterlogging
Clear weeds, crop residues, stones using hoe or tractor; compost or burn debris
Plough field to 15–20 cm depth with tractor or bullock plough; break clods
Plough again to ensure loose soil; remove remaining debris
Level field with plank or tractor leveller for even surface
Check field for low spots, fill them; smooth surface
Let field rest to settle soil; check pre-monsoon moisture
Collect 10–15 soil samples (15 cm depth) for nutrient and pH testing; send to lab
Apply lime (1–2 tons/ha) if acidic or gypsum (500 kg/ha) if alkaline; mix into soil
Spread 4–5 tons/ha decomposed farmyard manure (FYM)
Incorporate manure into soil with light harrowing
Apply basal fertilizers: 20–25 kg/ha N, 40–50 kg/ha P, 20 kg/ha K
Mix fertilizers into top 5–10 cm soil; avoid seed contact
Harrow lightly to create fine seedbed; remove clods
Buy 12–15 kg/ha certified Ujwala seeds; check germination (>85%)
Treat seeds with Rhizobium (200 g/10 kg) and Carbendazim (2 g/kg); dry in shade
notes: Enhances nitrogen fixation, prevents fungal diseases

tasks: Mark rows 60 cm apart using rope or plough; create 5–7 cm deep furrows
Prepare seed drill or plan manual sowing; clean tools
Sow seeds 15–20 cm apart in rows, 5–7 cm deep; place 2–3 seeds per hill
Cover seeds lightly with soil; protect from birds with scarecrows
Irrigate lightly (20 mm) if no rain; maintain 50–60% soil moisture
Check for germination (starts in 5–7 days); look for uniform emergence
Monitor for patchy germination; re-sow gaps if needed
Ensure soil remains moist but not waterlogged; irrigate (20 mm) if dry
Thin weak seedlings; keep one healthy plant per hill (55,000–60,000 plants/ha)
Remove thinned seedlings and weeds; dispose away from field
Irrigate lightly (20 mm) if rainfall low; check drainage
Observe seedling growth; ensure plants are 10–15 cm tall

week_5.title: Early Vegetative Growth and Weed Control

tasks: Weed manually with hoe around plants; remove all visible weeds
Apply Pendimethalin (1 kg/ha) if weeds heavy; spray within 2–3 days of sowing
Check for weed regrowth; pull out missed weeds
Inspect seedlings for yellowing or stunting; remove unhealthy plants
Irrigate (25 mm) if soil dry; use furrow irrigation
Monitor soil moisture with squeeze test; soil should form loose ball
Observe plant health; look for 4–6 leaves per plant
Apply 10–15 kg/ha nitrogen (25–30 kg urea); place 5–10 cm from plants
Incorporate urea into soil; irrigate lightly
Scout for aphids or jassids; spray neem oil (5 ml/L) if seen
Check for pod borer eggs on leaves; remove manually if low
Irrigate (25 mm) if no rain; ensure even distribution
Monitor plant growth; plants should be 30–40 cm tall
Rest fields; check for uniform vegetative growth
Weed manually or with hoe; keep rows clean
Check for weed regrowth; remove new sprouts
Scout for pod borer larvae or wilt symptoms; remove affected plants
Spray Monocrotophos (0.04%) if pests exceed 2–3 per plant; use safety gear
Irrigate (25 mm) if rainfall low; avoid waterlogging
Check soil moisture and drainage; ensure no waterlogging
Observe branching; plants should have 3–5 branches
Earth up soil around plant bases with hoe; strengthen roots
Continue earthing up; cover lower stems
Weed to remove late-emerging weeds; keep field clean
Check for missed weeds; pull out manually
Irrigate (25 mm) if dry; support flower bud formation
Monitor plant height (50–70 cm); check for leaning
Stake weak plants with bamboo if needed
Spray 2% DAP (20 g/L) on leaves in morning
Check spray coverage; ensure all plants treated
Irrigate (30 mm) to support flower bud formation
Monitor early flower buds; look for pest damage
Scout for pod borer on buds; use pheromone traps (5/ha)
Spray neem oil if pests seen; avoid spraying during flowering
Observe plant health; ensure no water stress
Check for yellow flowers (start 60–70 days after sowing)
Irrigate (30 mm) if rainfall low; support pollination
Monitor flower drop; check for stress
Scout for pod borer on flowers; spray Spinosad (0.02%) if needed
Check pheromone traps for pest activity; replace if full
Irrigate (25 mm) if dry; maintain consistent moisture
Remove dropped flowers to reduce pests
Spray 2% DAP to support pod setting; apply in morning
Check for powdery mildew; spray Mancozeb (2 g/L) if seen
Scout for pod fly on flowers; use sticky traps
Irrigate (30 mm) to support pod formation
Spray Indoxacarb (0.03%) for pod fly
Check flower-to-pod conversion; look for green pods
Remove weeds to reduce pest habitats
Check pod formation (7–10 days after flowering); count pods per plant
Irrigate (25 mm) to support pod growth
Scout for pod borer and pod fly; spray Chlorpyrifos (0.05%) if needed
Check traps for pest activity; remove damaged pods
Weed manually in inter-row areas
Irrigate (25 mm) if dry; support seed development
Observe pod health; ensure no fungal spots
Irrigate (25 mm) to support pod filling
Check for pod fly damage; spray if larvae seen
Monitor pod growth; pods should be green, firm
Stake leaning plants with bamboo
Check for pod bugs; use sticky traps
Irrigate (20 mm) if needed; reduce frequency
Observe plant health; remove diseased pods
Reduce irrigation (20 mm); check soil moisture
Scout for late pod fly; spray if damage >5%
Check pods for browning; seeds start hardening
Monitor weather for rain; plan harvest
Continue pest scouting; remove affected pods
Check pod maturity (80% brown); shake for seed rattle
Stop irrigation if pods browning
Cease irrigation; ensure good drainage
Check pod color (brown, hard); test a few pods
Scout for final pests; remove damaged pods
Monitor weather for harvest planning
Check pod moisture (10–12%); crack pods to test
Prepare harvesting tools (sickles, tarps); clean thoroughly
Observe field for uniform maturity; note green pods
Confirm 80–90% pods brown; check seed rattle
Stop all sprays to avoid residue
Plan harvest schedule; arrange labor or machinery
Check weather for dry conditions; avoid dew-heavy mornings
Clean sacks or baskets for pod collection
Walk field to confirm maturity; mark staggered harvest areas
Rest plants for natural drying; monitor pests
Stop all water inputs; allow pods to dry fully
Check pod readiness (90% brown); test pods
Arrange workers for harvesting; plan for early morning
Prepare clean tarps for pod collection; check equipment
Monitor weather for dry days; avoid rain
Sharpen sickles for clean cuts; ensure safety
Confirm field readiness; remove green pods for later
Harvest in morning using sickles; cut plants at base (7.5–25 cm stem)
Pick mature pods or cut whole plants; work carefully
Collect pods in clean sacks; avoid soil mixing
Continue harvesting mature pods; check uniformity
Stack plants in cubical shape for drying; spread on tarps
Transport pods to dry, clean area; protect from rain
Monitor drying pods; ensure even sun exposure
Dry pods in sun for 3–5 days; target 10–12% moisture
Turn pods daily for even drying; check for mold
Test pod moisture by cracking; seeds should be hard
Continue drying if needed; cover at night
Check for pest damage on pods; discard affected ones
Prepare threshing area; clean tarps or floors
Protect pods from rain; use tarps during showers
Thresh pods using sticks or thresher; work gently
Continue threshing; collect seeds in clean containers
Winnow seeds to remove chaff; use wind or fans
Clean seeds by sieving; remove small or damaged seeds
Grade seeds for size, color, quality; discard defects
Dry seeds to 8–10% moisture; spread thinly
Check seed hardness; ensure no soft seeds
Dry seeds to 8% moisture; turn frequently in sun
Treat seeds with neem leaves (1 kg/100 kg) or neem oil
Alternatively, use Aluminium Phosphide safely; follow guidelines
Pack seeds in airtight gunny bags or PICS bags; label
Store in cool, dry, ventilated area; elevate containers
Check storage humidity (<50%); inspect for pests
Re-treat with neem oil if pests appear
Inspect seeds for bruchids; remove infested seeds
Ensure storage is dry, cool (<30°C); ventilate well
Check seed quality; test germination
Re-fumigate if pests detected; use safe methods
Weigh seeds for market; use 50 kg bags
Prepare for sale; contact markets or cooperatives
Ensure bags sealed tightly; check for leaks
Sell seeds to markets or agencies; highlight Ujwala’s quality
Negotiate prices based on yield; check market rates
Clear field of crop residues; compost or burn safely
Plough field lightly for next crop; plan rotation (e.g., wheat)
Collect remaining debris; avoid pest carryover
Test soil for next season; plan nutrient management
Rest field or sow next crop; consult local experts

additional_notes: ICPL 14003 is resistant to sterility mosaic and Fusarium wilt, thrives in chalka soils, and fixes 40–60 kg/ha nitrogen
Seed priming (soaking in water/nutrients) can enhance germination in rainfed conditions
Use gravity separators or color sorters for precise seed grading
Apply Trichoderma viride or fungicides to prevent seed rot
Monitor storage with hygrometers; maintain <65% relative humidity
Value addition (de-hulling, milling) increases marketability; avoid overheating
Certify for organic/non-GMO standards for premium markets
Use pheromone traps for IPM during storage

tasks: Plough soil 15–20 cm deep with tractor or traditional plough to loosen it, improve water flow, kill pests
Clear old roots, stones, weeds by hand or machine to ensure clean field
Plough again and level field with leveler for even water spread
Spread 10–15 tons/acre well-rotted manure; mix into soil
Pick clean, healthy ICPH 2740 seeds from trusted supplier
Treat seeds with 2 g/kg Carbendazim or Thiram fungicide; dry in shade
Coat seeds with Rhizobium and PSB biofertilizers
Sow treated seeds 3–5 cm deep, 60 cm between rows, 20 cm between plants using seed drill or hand dibbling
Finish sowing entire field, keeping spacing and depth consistent
Cover seeds lightly with soil using rake
If soil dry and no rain, give light irrigation through furrows or sprinklers
Set up bird scarers like shiny CDs or scarecrows
Check for sprouting by gently scraping soil in random spots
Walk field to spot areas with no sprouts; mark for re-sowing
Count seedlings in 1 m² plots to check 80–90% germination
Mark spots with no seedlings using sticks or flags
Re-sow fresh seeds in marked gaps at 3–5 cm depth; water lightly
Remove weeds between plants with hand hoe, avoiding seedling damage
If soil dry, give light irrigation to support new seedlings
Check seedlings for yellowing or pests; ensure green, steady growth
(Optional) Spray 5% neem extract (50 ml neem oil + 1 tsp soap in 1 L water)
Check if seedlings are 4–6 inches tall and green
Lightly hoe between rows to loosen soil, remove small weeds
Apply 100 kg DAP, 25 kg Urea, 20 kg Potash per acre, 3–5 cm from plants; cover with soil
If dry, give light irrigation to aid nutrient absorption
Look for leaf curl, insects, or rotting stems
If pests seen, spray neem oil (5 ml/L water)
Remove big weeds; check plants are 15–20 cm tall with 5–6 leaves
Ensure plants are 20–30 cm tall with 6–8 green leaves, no pest damage
Use cultivator to loosen soil between rows when slightly moist
Hand-remove weeds near plant bases
Check for whiteflies, aphids under leaves, or curled leaves
If pests high, spray neem oil (5 ml/L) or Imidacloprid (0.3 ml/L)
(Optional) Spray micronutrients (5 g/L)
Clear fallen leaves; irrigate lightly if dry
Check if plants are 30–40 cm tall, forming side branches
Gently hoe near plants to remove small weeds, improve aeration
Look for aphids, mites, or sticky spots on plants
If pests present, spray neem oil (5 ml/L) or Thiamethoxam (0.3 g/L)
Spot wilting or yellow plants; uproot, destroy if wilt disease
Check soil moisture 5–10 cm deep; irrigate lightly if dry
Loosen soil between rows; add 10–15 kg/acre Urea if pale
Look for small buds, plants ~45–60 cm tall, green leaves
Spray DAP (20 g/L) + micronutrients (10 g/L) in morning
Pull weeds near plant stems
Check buds for caterpillars or beetles
If pests seen, spray neem oil (5 ml/L) or Spinosad (2.5 ml/L)
Check for yellowing or wilting; add Urea (10 kg/acre), irrigate
Ensure no pests/diseases, clean field, strong plants
Check for small yellow/white flowers on branches
Spray 2% jaggery solution (20 g/L water) to attract bees
Look for holes or caterpillars in flowers (pod borers)
If pests found, spray Helicoverpa NPV (250 LE/acre) or Spinosad (2.5 ml/L)
Check if flowers dropping; note if dry or pest-damaged
Spray NAA (40 mg/L) or Planofix (1 ml/L) to reduce flower drop
If soil dry, give light irrigation, avoiding water on flowers
Ensure most plants have open flowers, tiny green pods forming
Spray Boron (1 g/L) to improve pod setting, seed growth
Check for caterpillars, webbing in flowers/pods (pod borers)
If borers seen, spray Flubendiamide (0.3 ml/L) or Spinosad (2.5 ml/L)
Look for wilting or black stems; spray Copper Oxychloride (3 g/L) if fungal
(Optional) Spray 19:19:19 NPK (10 g/L) + micronutrients (5 g/L)
Irrigate lightly if soil dry, avoiding overwatering
Check if pods are 2–3 cm long, seeds firm when pressed
Irrigate lightly if dry, keeping water away from foliage
Spray 19:19:19 NPK (10 g/L) + micronutrients (5 g/L)
Look for holes in pods or caterpillars eating seeds
If pests found, spray Emamectin Benzoate (0.4 g/L) or Chlorantraniliprole (0.3 ml/L)
Check if pods maturing evenly; mark slow-growing plants
Look for white powder or dark spots; spray Carbendazim + Mancozeb (2 g/L)
Check if 70–80% pods are yellowish-green or brown, seeds hard
Stop all irrigation to avoid shattering or fungal issues
(Optional) Spray DAP (20 g/L) + micronutrients (10 g/L)
Squeeze mature pods to see if they split easily
Clear weeds; ensure good airflow
Check for powdery mildew or dark spots; spray Carbendazim + Mancozeb (2 g/L)
Pick sample pods, shell, check seeds for hardness, brown color
Confirm 85–90% pods brown, dry; seeds hard when bitten
Harvest in morning by cutting plants at base, bundling, sun-drying 1–2 days
Finish harvesting remaining plots; collect dried bundles
Beat bundles with sticks or use threshing drum; collect on clean sheet
Winnow pods using wind or fan to remove chaff, damaged seeds
Spread seeds in thin layer, dry in sun 2–3 hours, stir every 30 minutes to 10–12% moisture
Pack dried seeds in gunny/HDPE bags with neem leaves; store on pallets in cool, dry place
Check for new flowers or pods on side branches; monitor pests
If soil dry, give light irrigation to support late pods

Remove weeds; loosen soil between rows
Check pod maturity, leaf yellowing; note deficiencies

Look for wilting plants or white powder (powdery mildew)

Irrigate lightly if dry; clear weeds
Check 10–15 pods; seeds should be firm, yellowish

Look for sticky or curled leaves from aphids or whiteflies

Uproot, burn severely wilted or yellow plants
Clear weeds, fallen leaves
Irrigate lightly if late pods green, soil dry
Check if pods on all branches drying, leaves yellowing

Look for black or damaged pods (late pod borers)

Remove weeds, especially around field edges

Harvest areas with 85–90% dry pods, cutting plants, bundling
Continue harvesting dry patches; keep bundles separate

Clean, level threshing floor; spread tarpaulins

Harvest remaining mature plants when 75–80% pods light brown, cutting and bundling

Dry seeds in thin layer for 3–4 hours, stirring every 30 minutes, to 10–12% moisture
Sort seeds using sieves or air-screen cleaners; remove small, damaged ones

Inspect seed bags for moisture, mold, insect holes; restack if needed

Store seeds for next season in airtight drums or triple-layer bags with neem
Test germination by sprouting 100 seeds on moist cloth; aim for >85%
Check bags for beetles, larvae; re-treat with neem oil or fumigate if needed
Fix torn bags; ensure stacks low (7–8 bags) for airflow
Pack seeds for sale in 50 kg jute/polypropylene bags with labels
Arrange transport for buyers or share seeds with farmers
Record yield, costs, seed stock for planning
Check field for leftover stalks, roots, pods
Remove thick residues; stack for compost or fuel
Plough lightly to mix small residues into soil
Spread 5–10 tons/acre manure or compost

Sow green manure (e.g., sun hemp) or spread mulch
Inspect field for debris, waterlogging; note soil condition
Remove regrowth or weeds to prevent pest buildup

Inspect seed bags for pests, mold; dry or re-treat

Note field condition, pests, seed stock
Plan crop rotation (e.g., maize, groundnut)

Plough in 25–30-day-old green manure or sow new

Start fermenting Jeevamrut or Panchagavya
Check field for waterlogging, weeds; review crop plans
Remove new weeds or volunteer plants with hoe
Plough in 30-day-old green manure 6–8 inches deep
Check soil moisture; plough when it crumbles
Buy seeds, biofertilizers, manure for next crop
Stir, store Jeevamrut/Panchagavya or start now
Fix bunds or irrigation channels
Make calendar for next crop’s sowing, inputs, intercrop layout

additional_notes: ICPH 2740 yields 2407–3652 kg/ha, 40.7% higher than Asha, with resistance to Fusarium wilt, sterility mosaic
CMS-based seed production uses 500 m isolation, SSR markers for genetic purity
Rhizobium treatment enhances nitrogen fixation, reducing fertilizer needs
Suitable for deep black soils, rainfed/irrigated systems in Telangana
Post-harvest losses (15–20%) minimized by careful threshing, drying to 8–12% moisture
Hermetic storage (e.g., sealed drums) with desiccants (silica gel, calcium chloride) prevents pest infestation
Economic benefits from high yield, disease resistance reduce input costs
Seeds similar in size, color, taste to local varieties, accepted by consumers, millers

tasks: Select well-drained sandy loam field; collect soil samples for pH, N, P, K testing

additional_notes: ICPL 332 WR yields 1,500–2,000 kg/ha, resists Fusarium wilt, sterility mosaic, tolerates Helicoverpa pod borer
Medium-duration (150–180 days), 122 days to 50% flowering, indeterminate growth to 2 m
Green pods with purple streaks, light-yellow seeds with high market demand, good milling recovery
Rhizobium treatment enhances nitrogen fixation, reducing fertilizer needs
Non-lodging, upright plants with good branching suit red/black soils in Telangana
Post-harvest drying to 10% moisture, airtight storage with neem prevents bruchid/weevil damage
Grading, packaging in 50 kg gunny bags with labeling improves market price
Economic benefits from stable yields under stress, early maturity, and low disease losses
